comment: Recommended by guy at blend bar I'm indy
Light on the nose. Taste is sweet not much spice going on. Gets better after 1st sip.
V enjoyable. Couple of drops of water...Nice sweet finish.
The nose is unmistakably rye but its honeyed sweetness is more like a sherried Scotch. Lovely long finish with a hint of spice. Goes down far too easy given its strength.
Floral smell, taste of spicy turns to strong rye flavor. Oak finish.

Nose- Caramel rye on the initial nose, baked vanilla cake, 
Tasting- bourbon syrup dumplings, sweet but perfectly balanced rich bodied, very slight spice cinnamon on back pallet, hot cinnamon doughnuts drizzled with dark chocolate sauce, fantastic dram!
Oh wow....thats all i have to say...im in heaven.. golden syrup dumplins... or trycle..add a shard of ice and it brings in butternut snaps...

Nose - Vanilla, dark brown sugar, hint of dark cherries, very faint mint and possibly stale/old dill.
Taste - Hits the tongue spicy sweet of a vanilla caramel with a bit of freshly cracked black pepper. Cinnamon spice, faint mint/dill, buttery, yet dry.
Finish - Lingering buttery feel, cinnamon spice, mint is gone, but is more of a faint dill. Lightly oaky but almost no bitterness with a hint of slightly sour dark cherries.
85/100

So my note is actually for Pikesville Supreme 80 proof Straight Rye Whiskey. I tasted it against Rittenhouse, my favorite rye. The nose (Pikesville) initially was strongly ethanol with mint and oak, mellowing with time in the glass to a buttery caramel. I tasted grassy cereal before a quick spicey burn with anise that lasted through a long finish. With a few drops of water the nose turned slightly yeasty and the flavor was sweeter and the burn was slower. The finish was a nice lingering spicey anise glow. As nice a dram as it was though, it was hands-down advantage to the Rittenhouse which was sharper, cleaner, sweet-tartier (spell check didn't like that word), with a nicer oily-sweet lingering finish. FWIW, Old Overholt straight from a pocket flask had characteristics of both.
Lots of leather. Lots of spice. A little shallow on the end of the palate but for the price very good.

Nose: sweet vanilla, citrus
Palate: sweet and pepper and spice. 
Finish: tobacco smoke and leather
Nutmeg, butter, cocoa, dried cherries. Some vanilla and clove. Just a little smoke and leather. I'm in love.
Lots of spice on the nose. Good mouthfeel. Tons of rye. Lingering burn.

Gorgeous, rich nose: vanilla, creosote, an old leather armchair, cloves... the mouthfeel is amazing, fills your palate while toasting it with a pretty intense burn. Almost like it doesn't think you got enough up your nose already, so it tries the back door. Takes a couple of sips (or a bit of dilution) before the underlying flavours start to come through, but it's really all about the fire and spice. The finish is long, hot and full of flavours that you didn't even know were there: ginger biscuits, flamed orange peel, spiced mince pies, brandy soaked pannetone – there's nothing subtle about this whisky, it's a big rye-heavy punch on the nose; and its tremendous.
Adding water makes it very buttery

Go-to rye, 2nd best only to Willett 3yr Rye. Overall 6th best of 60+ bourbons and ryes ever tasted, just after Bookers, Willett 3yr Rye, Dickel 9yr, and Johnny Drum. Better than High West Double Rye, Knob Creek Rye, and Colonel Taylor Rye, Baby Sazerac, and Basil Hayden's. Much, much better than Redemption 8yr Barrel Proof Rye with its overly dry/dill/medicinal finish.  A few drops of distilled water helps this. Just sweet enough to pair well with nearly anything. Often I finish tastings with this, as it's still attractive even after trying 20 whiskies. I look forward to comparing with High West Rendezvous Rye and Michter's Barrel Proof Rye (which is supposed to be slightly better, though at much higher cost). Higher proof, better aged version of Rittenhouse Rye.
Spicy nose, plenty of warmth. Hot going down with moor spicy characteristics. Needs some water to settle down. Flavorful, rich and full bodied. Plenty of spice flavor through long finish
I like this eye. Easy and butter smooth
Homemade Oatmeal cream pie taste says the wife
Nice. Sweet and long on the tongue. Slightly spicy but no burn. Very bold flavor.
great everyday rye, nice pop at 110 but enjoyable, great mixer

Intense nose that clears the sinuses. Sweet cereal flavor with a touch of pepper. Has a sweet Cheerios cereal finish that turns into spice. Thanks JT.
Mashbill: 51% rye, 35% corn & 14% malted barley.
Incredibly smooth, should drink straight not on rocks
Smooth for a 110-proof. Great nose; burnt sugar, vanilla, floral notes. Those notes as well as leather on the palate. Bitterness on the finish. 5/11/17.

Spicy on the front but ends in a very sweet vanilla. Also long finish

Tried at husk- May 6
First time not enjoyed. Second time spicy, dry, lasting.

Maryland versus Pennsylvania is *the* rye debate. OK, maybe not, but much like how much of Western philosophy can be (over)reduced to a question of Plato vs Aristotle, rye whiskey tends to fall, for me, into two categories: mellower, sweeter ryes with plenty of other grains (usually corn) in the mash bill (aka Maryland style ryes), or punch-you-up spicy ryes that usually have very little of anything else in them (Pennsylvania style ryes). This is Maryland through and through, with a rich mouthfeel that delivers plenty of cinnamon, caraway, and spice, with the tiniest hint of dill, but wrapped up in enough of a blanket of caramel sweetness to soften the impact. Very enjoyable stuff!
4.5 really.  Lots of heat but it doesn't linger.  Rye flavor is good but not as big and bold as Willet.  Almost muted.

3/28/17 Fairview Liquor & Fine wines
Fairview, TN. ~$55 + tax

Thick, oily, viscous mouth feel. Cereal grains are abundant, along with the typical bourbon caramel and sweetness. The finish has leather notes that I appreciate. A good introduction to rye for those unfamiliar and want to try something new, where other, more herbal ryes may be jarring.
woody aroma, sweet dry sip with slight burn, slow burn follow with spicy swallow
Buttery and wonderful cask strength rye

Thanks to [email protected], I got to sample this one.  First of all...that ABV will fool you.  It's potent, but it's silky smooth, so you can't even feel the heat or burn.  I was surprised the nose didn't give an earlier indicator of how strong this would be.   I didn't get the typical rye flavors of mint-eucalyptus, but instead a more chocolate-y leather profile...like a Speysider or Highlander.  Really a great sipper...add a touch of water, and the flavors open up.  Thanks Richard!

Very strong 3-4 drops of water apple and sweet vanilla cream
$48

Proof is noticeable on the nose also light brown sugar notes and cocoa. Palette is likewise sweet and not peppery. Some warmth on the finish. Pleasant and enjoyable. As it sat it moved from peppery to cocoa and dusty to grainy. 
Compared it to Lock Stock & Barrel 13, and WhistlePig 100/100 single barrel cask strength. The proofs were close. Pikesville was decidedly single noted comparatively but was able to stay in the race especially at the relative price point.
Solid Rye whiskey. One of the good ones.
Deep rich mouth coating. Long finish. A lot of wood and char. Nice all around

Excellent value.  It's a softer gentler rye.  Good introduction for bourbon drinkers given its high corn content.  Arrival is sweet with caramel.  You get the rye notes in the development and finish.  Cereal and biscuit notes.  A hint of spices and not not much pepper.  I get a subtle chocolate note.  Even at 110 it handles well.  A touch of heat but is balanced well.
brilliant. notes of caramel, wood, and spices. good price hangs in with expensive/hard to find thomas handy

If nothing else, the bottle itself is beautiful. Unremarkable colour (especially considering the high proof), and a nose that I would initially describe as . . . dusty. Just dust, caked dirt, gritty, something akin to a dry farmhouse. Persist and you get some nice baking and brining spice (lots of clove, anise, caraway seed, a touch of dill, faint mint), vanilla, fresh-cut lumber, and faint sweet cherry and grape. Surprisingly little burn at 110 proof, though the heat builds considerably on the tongue. A flavour that's quite mild--initial fresh grain, baking and brining spices, but it's an oddly thin character at this proof, and it's buttressed by a lot of dry-wood, toothpick-y bitterness. A bit of vanilla, faint cherry, apple and applewood. But a lot of fairly harsh graininess.  And a surprisingly short finish as well, that's dry and tannic. A bit of cinnamon and apple after a few sips. Curiously--and I'd have to do a side-by-side to confirm this--a bit of a disappointment: a notch below Rittenhouse for me, even at a much-inflated price. Not terrible, but stick with the Ritt.

Note- very pleasant maple syrup 
Body- dry with a bit of pepper and  light cloves
Finish- hot to sweet with a bit of that briny note I get in rye

Note- I like this a lot better the second time. Warms my head and not my chest. Easy to drink slowly. I don’t recommend drinking quickly.

Color: Dark Amber

Nose: Vanilla, ripe apple, then caramel with a very light hint of oak at the end.

Palate: Lighter bodied and velvety mouth feel. Caramel and fruit at front with a spiciness that warms up to a lingering spicy and fruity finish.

Nose: ethanol, sweet and spicey rye

Palate: Smooth for a rye, not overly complex.  Proof is more in the nose, no burn.  Leaves a nice spiced finish on the tongue.

I’m reviewing the 110 proof

Nose is piney and ethanol very herbaceous and forest like some anise and maybe some dill

Palate is full and warm with typical rye spice

Sort of unremarkable. Certainly not bad but nothing that makes me think this is a must have.

Nose: cinnamon, vanilla, so much spice 

Taste: serious cinnamon all spice, pepper, followed by waves of vanilla and sweetness. Caught a slight cola and an apple pear note

The finish has a slight lingering burn with that sweet vanilla caramel lingering. 

My favorite rye
Smooth Carmel notes, heavy burn back.  Toasted back

Classification: Straight Rye
Proof: 110 (45%)
Age: 6+ Years
Mashbill: 39% Corn, 51% Rye, 10% Malted Barley)
Distillery: Heaven Hill Distillery, Bardstown, KY
Price: $45 - $55
Color: Medium-Dark Copper
Nose: Sweet, Spicy, Cinnamon, Cherry Cola,
Palate: Sweet, warm, rich & creamy, spiced cherry cola, vanilla
Finish: Long, Persistent Heat, Spicy, Oak
Personal Rating: 7/10
Notes: This is my first time reviewing a rye whiskey. I’ve historically been pretty stuck in just bourbons, but have been enjoying ryes more as of late. There is two things I can say about tasting Pikesville 6 Year: I pick up quite a bit of Mr. Pibb flavor in here, from the nose into the finish there are notes of spiced cherry cola throughout; I’m definitely not mad about that. Secondly, this pour is not only spicy, it is hot. The heat persists from the first sip all the way the finish. Because of this, a few drops of water would do you good if the heat is a little much for you. Once the heat dissipates...say a minute or two after you drink, I start to taste come candy sweetness back in my cheeks. Ultimately, the flavor is solid, the color is gorgeous, and it comes in a handsome bottle, a nice addition to any collection
To me this is what all of the ryes  should be compared to. For $50 it’s a bargain.
Caramel and oak. Very nice, not as harsh as you expect for the strength.
Nose - Oak, vanilla, caramel. Taste - Spicy rye across the tongue, cereal, vanilla, oak, chocolate.

Dark amber in color. Lighter bodied whiskey with a velvety mouth feel. 

Nose: soft vanilla sweetness with ripe apple followed by a bit of caramel and a little oak in the back. Zero ethanol despite the 110 Proof.

Palate: caramel sweetness and rich fruit at the front, spiciness heats up in the middle. Finish is medium length and fairly hot but still pleasant and not all that dry, with lingering caramel and spice.

I’d give it above a 4.5/5 so 5 stars on here 🥃
A very smooth whiskey with a sweet and very rich flavor. Nice vanilla flavor to finish

Paid $39.99 @ BevMo ($49.99 minus a $10 coupon).
At this price point, I don't think you can find a better Rye. Right upon entry you are hit with Vanilla, brown sugar and maple syrup. Pretty viscous for a 6 yr old Rye and baking spices begin to swell on the mid palatte. Finish is long with a kick of clove and a spicy oak finish. Incredibly smooth for 110 proof. Other than coming from the same distillery, it really doesn't share the same flavor profile as Rittenhouse. It is a superior dram in every way. Strong recommendation! 4.5/5

Pikesville Straight Rye is a "barely legal" rye whiskey, as its mashbill contains the minimum amount of rye (51%) to be called a rye whiskey.  As a result, the spice and the bite of the rye is softened by the  sweetness of the high corn content (39%).  Aged for six years in new charred oak barrels, the influence of the casks adds depth and complexity to the flavor profile.  At 55% ABV Pikesville drinks very well at full strength with very little alcohol burn.  However, I find that a splash of water opens up the whiskey, bringing out more dark fruit.  NOSE: Vanilla, Oak, Cherry Cola, Leather, Dill, Anise, Baked Apple, Cinnamon, Toffee.  PALATE: Caramel, Vanilla, Dark Fruit, Spicy Oak, Leather, Cinnamon, Dill.  FINISH: Dry... Oak, Leather, Dark Fruit, Cinnamon, Dill, Anise.  Pikesville is an incredible value at $50 and merits 4.5 stars.  I wish it had a higher rye content, but that's a minor complaint.
Tasted at Whiskey Obsession 2018. Take Rittenhouse, flip the front and the finish backwards, and add a bit of time. Good.

I might be the outlier here; it's good but not my favorite...

The nose is nice: sweet, herbaly with notes of dill and oak. 
The palate loses me: it's hotter than I like and more on the bitter end, notes of leather and menthol. Finishes dry.
2018 rye whiskey of the year (<10 yrs). Found bottle in Kentucky across river from Cincinnati.

Really smooth, not Spicy for a rye. Love the 110 proof full body flavor. No way you guess this is 110proof in a blind taste test. This is one of my favorite whiskeys and has become a staple at my house. Dollar for dollar you are going to have an extremely hard time matching the quality.

I think the best thing about this whiskey is that it is like a high rye bourbon. Its really really rich yet its really smooth with very little rye bite, but still that good rye flavor. Its just a really great drink.
Smooth, little burn on back; but very low.
spicy, but delicious with a few drops of water. notes of vanilla.
A very smooth rye and leaves a lasting Smokey flavor on your tongue. A great rye for the price.
The smoothest rye I’ve ever tasted.

Nose: 3.5 | sweet - black fruit/cherries, slight spice
Palate: 3.75 | big mouthfeel, sweet upfront, cherry syrup, anise, licorice
Finish: 3 | long, slight oak and spice
Value: 3.5 
    
Verdict: Bar
I really wanted to love this but just couldn't.  There was something almost medicinal about the finish that was a bit of a turnoff.  Great in a Manhattan though.

Sweet grass and peppery grain on the nose. 110 and a little hot without ice, but rich, spicy grain, and vanilla oak and leather in the mouth. Clean smokey finish. Neat or with an ice cube, and great in a cocktail.
warming with notes of honey and spice. Andrea liked.
Honey on the nose, salty, cherry on the tongue. Surprisingly smooth for a Rye.
After the front end, it’s very smooth.  This is at 110 proof, so pretty remarkable!

Tastes like a cherry vanilla Coke that was infused with red hots candy, leather, and oak. Doesn't have quite the "bite" as E.H. Taylor Straight Rye, which is has more pepper and spice, and drinks surprisingly smooth despite being higher in proof. Overall, not the most complex Rye whiskey but a rich, and smooth experience that will have you going back for more. This will definitely become one of my go-to daily drinkers.
Fantastic rye! The finish just lingers on, brilliant stuff. Everything just works so well together for this dram. The proof, the right amount of spicyness, the lovely rye bread nose. Magical!

I love Rittenhouse and after reading reviews, I was wondering is it could be worth almost twice the price of Rittenhouse. I seriously think so. Less but than Rittenhouse despite a tasty 110 proof, complex, rich, spicy, it is simply delicious
Good amount of heat in back end. Needs ice and bitters
Super dry finish. A definite face punch at 110 proof, but a smooth and earthy hit follow by an almost port wash. Easy and hot with a slight tobacco finish.

Whoa.  Really really incredible stuff.  Love this and it will not be my last bottle.

Herbal, slightly medicinal nose.  Marjarom, mint, and vanilla.  Little to no ethanol, a surprise at 110 proof.  Pleasant and clean.  Medium body with noticeable legs.  A rich, reddish amber.

Gently sweet on the tongue, then cherries, peppercorn, and mint flash across the palate.  Classic herbal rye notes prevail with a long, gently spicy finish.  Quite well balanced and smooth, it gives no hint of the proof.  Approachable and wonderful neat.
Initial bite of a rye with a smooth finish, woody note. A rye for bourbon drinkers

Tea and sour/tart taste. Also citrus

Finish: Damn.

surprisingly calm nose. more leather and butterscotch notes on light nose.
    
    deep nose very smooth, no spice or burn. I'm intrigued...
    
    first drink surprisingly alive following that nose. great flavor, but short. Let's see how second taste goes.
    
    getting more vanilla on this nose. More burn, but just ate a chip that skewed the palette.
    
    Tasted Noah's Mill and Pikesville next to each other - Pikesville has more spice, almost mintish note...  I think I'm appreciating ryes more...
Very good rye.  Spicier than most especially considering the high corn content.

I know that Rittenhouse seems to be the Rye of choice when it comes to Heaven Hill but I have to throw my support behind Pikesville. I say this with a healthy appreciation of Rittenhouse but for me, Pikesville just has a little something extra. The bump in proof goes a long way and this Rye has a few extra dimensions for me that Rittenhouse is lacking, tasting more refined and nuanced, at least to my palette. I love Ritt in a cocktail but it’s not a Rye I’d feel the need to sip per say. Pikesville I could go in either direction. Anywho, just my pair of pennies. Cheers!
Brown sugar followed by a lot of spice. Not enjoyable for most right out of the bottle. Would definitely recommend a little water. But one of the few ryes I would keep coming back for.
This is an amazingly flavorful wiskey. I have done a few side by side vs. other Rye's and it beats them all due to the flavors, smoothness and complexity.
Lots of heat in this rye. Nose-  alcohol, palate- spicy and rich. Finish- heat

Went & bought one after the advent calendar.  

Really like it still !

Advent Calendar 2018

We liked this one!!!
Bit of a bite and aftertaste.

Straight up. Pretty bad. Even after giving it some air and waiting a week. Turpentine, alcohol, not much spice. I don’t like to admit this after paying $45 for this, but I even prefer 1776 better which is bottom shelf IMHO.
I really liked this. Had it with a little water and ice. I might like the Highwest Double Rye a little more but it's close. Much more spicy.
For a new whiskey guy, this hurts. We’ll talk later though.

3cL Sample from Fine Drams of the 6-yr

Nose: vanilla, orange zest, butterscotch
Palate: Wet cereal with milk. Just a ton of that vanilla. Hides proof well.
Finish: Moderately long. Pepper, leather, smoke

Water opens this one up really well.  I think this is a good $50 bottle. I may purchase to try in an OF, as the sample isn't adequate for that.
Very tasty. Lots of flavor with clean finish.
Quite delicious when diluted down to about 90 proof. Has a great spicy nose and quite a bit of complexity hiding behind the burn. Plenty of oak, tobacco and vanilla linger on the rye spiced finish.

Nose: vanilla, toasted oak, caramel, toffee
Palate: strong, but nice oak flavor throughout, vanilla, heavy rye spice, and leather 
Finish: complex: vanilla, cinnamon, rye,  honey
Surprisingly good.  Very smooth and to the point.  Enjoyed in South Carolina with Dwight Olson.
definite spice and a smooth natural burn. lingers a bit, has a nice bite..

Just amazing, ice opens it up for sure, nice spice and oak on the front side but balanced by some sweetness as well, finish is leather, some tobacco and sticks around long enough to bring a smile to your face.  My favorite Rye and another example of the exemplary whiskies Heaven Hill is producing.

Sweet vanilla and clove nose. Spices comes through in the roof of your mouth. Slightly leather yeast flavor follows. Fairly smooth for the alcohol content, but nice warm chest at the end. Benefits nicely with ice bringing more flavor depth.
Smoky leather with hints of dark chocolate, not your classic rye

Nose: caramel or maybe chocolate, cinnamon or a baking spice, pine needles - basically something like a Christmas cookie
Taste: spicy, rye, salty, not much sweetness
Finish: hot and dry, rye but neither pickle or licorice 
After reading reviews: flaviar and whizzky had clove and I’d agree that is a better descriptor than what I said was cinnamon.  Cocoa also was noted, as was the overly spicy rye character that dominated for me.  Reviews cited more sweetness in the taste than I got.  Overall, this was maybe too much rye for my tastes which is good to know.
Sweet, cherry and vanilla balanced rye.
Spicy quick burn up front smoothing out to a nice finish with hints of Carmel and chocolate. Not rye flavor at all, making it my favorite rye.

opening bottle....  really nice.  not over rye, just enough. 

2 months later....  way, way more earthy notes and less sweet notes.  barrel shows up too.  water helps open up more soft, sweet flavors.  not bad by any means, just not RR SB Rye....

Wow the spice! Good stuff. Bought this in the basis of Jim Murray’s whiskey bible and this certainly didn’t leave me upset but at the same time I’m not overwhelmed with how great it is as Jim describes. Would certainly buy again but for no more than $40 so it looks as though I won’t be buying it again.
Nose is extraordinary—caramel, toffee, vanilla, brown sugar. Taste mostly follows suit with a good balance of rye spice, but a little too hot for its own good. Ice opens it up a bit.
Strong burn even with a squirt of water.

So much going on in the nose. I’m not good enough to pick out most of it. I get snickerdoodle cookies and cherries. The mouthfeel is velvety and delightful. Tastes like berry crisp. The heat is there but not overpowering. The finish goes long and strong with earthy notes, even a touch of salty air. A little water brings out some type of berry note. This is really good stuff l!
Too spicy for my taste. Feels young.

Bottle code A2025 12 52
Nose: 
Baking spice rye bread
Sweet air
Hint of sawdust 

Palate:
Orange peel
Rye funk
 Finish medium 

In a lot of ways drinks similar to Old Granddad 114 for me
Smooth front and finish but it has a delightful spicy note on the finish.
High rye, tried at Heaven Hill distillery. Won’t buy a bottle
Too hot to find the flavor. Added a bit of water and it was better. Will try it again.

I think it good but not amazing! I would say anyone who likes Rye needs to taste Angels Envy Rye  Finished in Rum Barrels. Delicious!! Distiller Lincoln Henderson deserves to be called "Master Distiller"
This is my new favorite Rye.

Nose: Sweet vanilla, cinnamon spice, pastry batter, tobacco.

Taste: Cinnamon sugar, vanilla frosting, nutmeg, leather.

Experience: Waking up late on a Saturday to hot cinnamon rolls.
Too spicy and strong for my taste. High West Double Rye, Sazarac Rye & Rittenhouse Rye are still my Top 3.
110 proof but quite smooth! Nice spice. Slight floral notes. Carmel color. Delicious
solid rye offering; more oak on the pallette than others; very smooth with good rye notes
So smooth esp for a higher proof. Rye spices moderated by full body and sweet grains. One of my favourite ryes.

Beautiful nose. Like a bouquet of caramel, vanilla and honey. 

On the palate, it sipped lower than its proof. Loads of spice, light vanilla and toffee sweetness.

Finished with dark chocolate, rye spice, and cherries.

Water made it much more aggressive, so add it if you’re looking to get punched. 

Overall a very solid rye

55% abv (110 proof)

Nose: vanilla, sugar cookie and creamy rye spice. Almost dessert like. Touch of ginger and a hint of mint in the background.

Palate: caramel and big rye spice dominate; vanilla and brown sugar compliment on the development; hint of tart apple at the end; full, soft and mouth-coating texture.

Finish: medium length, nearly perfect balance of rye spice and bourbon notes; juicy fruit and spearmint and hint of cocoa pop up on the tail end.

Value: $45-55 bucks American. Worth it.

Final thoughts: this is simply a great rye whiskey that fits all moods. The rye spice is robust but not overpowering, leaving room for the barrel influence to shine. A dash or two of water balances this pour even further, making it enjoyable for high proof lovers as well as rye novices.

Score:

4/5

Recommend buying a bottle.
Sweet like bourbon up front and spicy in the back.
This rye is much sweeter than most, but still has a good balance if spice. Body is full and creates a good finish.

Nice amber color. Nose is harsh, but then again it is 110 proof. Nose gives slight floral notes and a lot of that rye smell. 

Taste is a little harsh and fiery at first, but finishes strong with the lingering malt/grain tastes
Hits the palate (extra) sweet initially, and then bam - spicy pepper right at ya.   Nice.  Worth a shot if you dig the sweetness upfront.   Love the spicy finish on this one.

sweet nose with a slight maple and brown sugar oatmeal aroma.

not a big spice on first sip like most rye's, sweet and tobacco finish.
Hot hot hot. Classic rye, not a fan

Nose:
Barrel funk, rye spice, powdered sugar, soft dill, powdered chocolate 
Palate: 
Cherry, licorice, honey, sugary sweetness 
Finish:
Warming spice, citrus, oak

Amazing nose of cinnamon sugar, butter, and baking spices. Some gingerbread as well. Literally smells like a Snickerdoodle cookie. Could be the best aroma I have ever sampled on a whiskey.

Everything in the aroma carries over into the taste which opens with sweet cinnamon, nut, and black cherry notes and then switches to a spicy almost chili pepper like finish. Not a lot of herbaceousness to this for a rye; just a hint of anise, clove, tobacco, and mint in the finish. Tastes more like a high-rye bourbon, but in my opinion is not a bad thing at all.

Mouthfeel is vicious and chewy. Finish is medium to long with a cocoa powder note coming after everything else fades. 

Can’t recommend this enough. Just delicious from start to finish.

Bottom line upfront, this is delicious. The nose is somewhat alcohol forward with notes of baked bread, earthy barrel char, baking spice, and a hint of dried leather in the background. The palate is very sweet with notes of maple, ginger, spiced apples, and cinnamon. Digging a little deeper, burnt brown sugar and dry roasted peanuts present themselves in the background. This tastes pretty smooth for being 110 proof. The finish gives way to notable spice that peaks and subsides into a long, oily finish with a subtle burn slowly tapering off into a final hint of bitter chocolate.

Aroma: Dusty cocoa notes with oaky smoke underneath. 

Taste: Dry and spicy, with honeyed rye and cloves.
Creamy, sweet notes.  Picking up leather and some chocolate on the finish.  Easy to drink.

Nose: peanuts, ethanol, barrel spice, subtle vanilla, oatmeal 
Palate: sweet, cinnamon, pepper, surprisingly little heat
Finish: chocolate, tobacco, oak, long finish with heat at the end

Very easy sipper for 110, but pretty light spice for a rye
A solid rye. Not too spicy as other eyes get. Opens up nicely with water. Full and leathery with a good burn, but not overpowering. Better than the Rittenhouse from same Heaven Hill distiller.
Has the strong rye finish - heat and pepper. Great smooth start with fresh taste!
Sweet on the nose, root beer float. Vanilla, spice; continuing on palate; finish is consistent
Been waiting to try this. Wow! Fantastic. Smooth, strong vanilla, leather, and I swear some chocolate on the finish. Like a sundae. Expected more spice and less sweet but not complaining. Must get.
Very good rye. In my opinion it’s the Buffalo Trace of rye. Good everyday rye.

Take the last train to Pikesville and I'll meet you at the station,
be there by 4:30 for I've made your reservation..

Ok enough Monkeeying around,  (inspired by Olddude and maybe 4 other guys), Pikesville is a pretty heady rye, with a rich nose of sweet red hots and oranges and a touch of lemon grass, a nod of leather(old english) I like the direction Heaven Hill is going with this one.

Front: as advertised it is a rich dose of hot and spicy rye, there is no mistaking the distinct rye grain taste with some chaff and dusty barrel treatment riding shotgun.  Some dark brown sweetness, almost a molasses, makes a short appearance in the middle.   Anise and clove with nibs..(thanks Fafnir)

FInish: tapers off warm and salty, the rye grain is never ending loads of it and still warm burning down the gullet and yet smooth with hints of citrus.

After all this is a stout and only mildly cut, high proof libation,  this may be a serious rye drinkers rye as much as Willet or Whistle Pig considering the full bodied notes and lack of impurity.  The pricing on this bottle tends to be a bit high but there is a lot to offer here, I can get behind the idea of this being a "go to"  bottle, much like the Knob and Russels Single Barrell ryes.  It seams Heaven Hill has their own entry in the serious but not exorbitantly priced  ryes market as well. 

Certainly a bottle any serious rye drinker would want but maybe not one that a novice rye drinker is ready for, a decent HH product all the same.

My favorite ryes to date are Peerless and Angel's Envy. At half the cost and better availability, this is a no brainer for me. Rich, sweet and spicy. I actually think i like it better than Peerless. More character to me.
One of my favorite ryes to date.

Tastes like Bourbon with a substantial Rye kick. The heat level matches the beautiful flavor profile and makes for a very nice pour that makes you want to shout “Yum!”. I was lucky enough to find this on sale for $35....should have bought two dammit.

110 Proof Pikesville Straight Rye. This Bad Boy of Rye is flavor busting, but with a very unique deep rich flavor profile, different than anything I have tasted before. The nose and taste of this reminds me of pecan shortbread cookies my wife makes for Christmas, that she dips half of each cookie in dark chocolate. Needless to say the nose is wonderful. The flavors are bursting with the bakery spices, chocolate, a good nuttiness, and shortbread cookies. This is a great flavor bomb and very unique too boot. The heat level is a little hot, but doesn't get in the way. Perfect sipper neat in a glencairn. I like Rittenhouse, but this Pikesville takes it off the charts. Great whiskey that I can get for mid 50's, and I'll say its worth it. I will get this again for a nice change and let me remind you - This Is Not A Normal Rye! Which is a good thing in this case! Recommended *This is now my top favorite rye.*
Comes in hot, spicy and sweet. Easy sipper.  Clearly one of my favorite rye whiskies.

You know those drams where you wonder what it would be like if you could bump the ABV up to 46%, or the drams that make you wish they had a bit more depth of flavor, or the drams you wish you could turn the intensity up a few notches? 

This is not one of those drams. 

Enter Pikesville Straight Rye.  There’s been a lot of chatter about this rye recently, and even I had seek out a pour of it before hunting down a bottle (I previously reviewed this on the fly). When I found it on special for $40, I couldn’t resist. Let’s see this bottle’s specs. 

Mash Bill: 51% Rye, 35% Corn, 14% Malted Barley
Age: 6 years
ABV: 55%
Price: $39.99 (typically seen for $40-$50)

Nose: Rich and sweet. Red vine licorice, candied cherries, vanilla, rye spice, and burnt caramel with a bit of the accompanying smoke. All of this is enveloped in the aromas of a walk-in cigar humidor. The proof is suspiciously concealed. 

Palate: Rich, full-bodied, fruity, and spicy. The sweetness is definitely there but it’s almost an afterthought because there’s so much else going on.  Woody cigar tobacco, more red vine licorice, cherry syrup, and burnished crème brûlée crust. A tiny bit of balancing salt. Dangerously drinkable at full strength, water is unnecessary. 

Finish: My goodness, this is long and it hangs around afterwards. I’m curious if it smells like I was steeped in tobacco after drinking this. More spice and oak, leather, and burnt caramel sweetness. 

Overall Impressions: Highly enjoyable dram. I tasted this alongside it’s younger cousin, Rittenhouse Rye Bottled-in-Bond (review for this forthcoming). I’m finding conflicting information on Rittenhouse’s mash bill (I also found conflicting information on Pikesville’s mash bill until I confirmed it on a Heaven Hill page) and after tasting these side-by-side, it’s hard to imagine it’s just 2 years of age separating them. So I’m calling them cousins instead of brothers until this is clearer to me.

Verdict: This begs the question - if you could only have 1 rye....?  I’m unabashedly loyal to Rittenhouse for the balance of price, quality, and adeptness as a mixer. I imagine Pikesville could also be a great mixer, but at $40+ and with all these rich flavors, it would be remiss of me to cover them up. So I’d want to keep Rittenhouse around for my Manhattans and Pikesville for my sipper.*

For now, I’m feeling pretty good about sticking with my original rating of 4.0, but I’m very curious how this will evolve over the course of the bottle.**

4.0 ~ 88 ~ Great

*As a little tasting experiment, I also poured myself some Michter’s US*1 Single Barrel Straight Rye, a bottle Distiller describes as “Rich & Full Bodied”. Now, I know full well that this was a bit of an unfair comparison given how intense I knew the Pikesville was, but I did it any way for curiosity’s sake. The Michter’s transformed into a light, herbal, floral, and fruity dram, attributes not typically ascribed to it en masse. I won’t be writing up a review of this tasting of the Michter’s because it was a bit unfair, but it just goes to show you how powerful and rich the Pikesville is. 

**I’m also curious to see how Pikesville stacks up against its up-and-coming NAS brother, Elijah Craig Rye, which will launch with a limited release in January 2020 and is confirmed to share the same mash bill as Pikesville. Here’s to hoping I can get my hands on some to compare!
Flavor profile was lacking to me, and the higher proof wasn't as pronounced as I had hoped. Will revisit this in the future.

Nose: Comes in with a bit of nose hair scorching heat. Baked bread, cherry wood, and a kiss of spearmint. 

Palate: Richness is the key here. That baked bread with roasted almonds, homemade applesauce, and a round full baking spice.

Finish: This whiskey keeps going with it's finish. The age is noticeable with cinnamon and sweet oak, cigar tobacco, and a touch of leathery dryness. 

This is a great rye. Buy it!
That’s got some oomph to it! Love it!
High rating for a Rye...Distiller notes spot-on.   It's better with ice.  I tried neat but was overwhelmed with rye spices.  The ice brings out the flavors.

This is great, whether you like Rye whiskey or not do yourself a favor and try this.  Smooth and buttery with a nice combination of baking spices and dark red fruits.  For price point ($44) , proof (110) , and age (6+ years), this is a damn good dram.

N - spice and vanilla caramel butterscotch

P - vanilla, red fruit, spice

F - long and smooth with the spice and leather.

Can't pull out a lot of individual flavors but really enjoy.  Very smooth for proof.
Earthy, molasses, chocolatey, spicy taste, a little bitter at the end
Green apple, dark syrup, spiced fruit, caramel, warm

Full, rich, sweet, and spicy taste profile, the best characteristics of a Rye whisky. I could regularly sip on this any day and every day. However, unless it was at least a Single Barrel, it's very difficult to accept its MSRP price tag. But it is definitely one of those whiskys one needs to try in life. You won't regret it.
Wet grassy hay nose. Initial taste is a sweet hit, then spearmint, licorice tailing off to just-mowed grass.
Very strong taste, hard on the side of the tongue and back of the throat. Not my favorite rye by a long stretch
Pretty solid rye. Nose is vanilla, caramel and spice. Taste is rye spice and fruit notes. Finish is nice and long with plenty of spice

Let’s get this out of the way early. I’m not a big rye fan. 

For me, rye is like the girl you keep going back to even though she inevitably burns you every time. Rye is my ex-girlfriend of the whiskey world. 

Moving on. In my latest transgression, I’ve seen a whole lotta chatter here and on YouTube about Pikesville. Pikesville is different they say. It’s a “barely legal” rye (a term I still don’t much care for). I thought to myself, “Balcones rye beat you up, Lot 40 was fun at first but then wrecked you, but maybe this time it’ll be better.” 

Well, so far so good. 

It looks like a rye, and smells like a rye, but the minute it hits your lips, it gets sweet. Sure there’s the spice, but it’s dressed up, gentler. That gives way to more brown sugars, cigar tobacco, and some caramel. It’s almost a bourbon in rye clothing. The finish from that 55% lingers but she’s warm and kind, not aggressive and temperamental like some ryes can be. This rye is all right. Maybe this one won’t burn me. Maybe this time it’ll be different. Maybe this rye is the one.

Ive seen glowing reviews on this(really high score at Whiskey Jug) and was excited to try. This is basically Rittenhouse100 aged two more years with 10 more proof. Pikesville is only $11 more in my neck of the woods($39.99). Poured neat, nice dark color with nose of baking spices, cotton candy, smoky oak, dusty rye and faint dill. There is a whiff of ethanol but not overbearing. 110pf coats the glass well and has oily mouthfeel. Palate is a juggernaut of sweet spice, cooked molasses, burnt pie crust, raw vanilla, rye and oak with smoky heat throughout. Rich and absolutely delicious! It runs a little hot at proof yet still remains smooth. Finish goes into next week with lasting sweet smoky charred wood, toasty cinnamon and rye spice. Bold, brash and full of flavor the extra proof really bringing it. The powerful taste delivery reminds me of Old Grand Dad 114. If you are a fan of ryes buy it, its exceptional !! You will not be sorry......98/100.......New top dog rye for me. Going through this bottle Im now picking up a wonderful rich chocolate note. This rye is truly complex and fantastic!!...

So I checked out a new whisk(e)y spot that was recommended to me.  I liked the atmosphere of the place, but most of the pours were ridiculously overpriced.  Sure, there were some harder to find bottles (some Hibiki and BTAC to tempt me....) but don’t get me started on the prices (let’s just say $300 and up and we’re not talking about Port Ellen’s or Brora’s).  The list of highway robberies goes on and on.  $120 for a pour of Glendronach 19? $100 for Balvenie 21?  $80 for a pour of Birthday Bourbon?  Seriously?  These were not “venti”-sized pours either. 

Not to be deterred, and not to turn it into an evening of settling for overpriced cocktails, I did locate a bottle of the Pikesville Straight Rye tucked away on a shelf. 

For the sake of brevity and in light of the setting, I will treat this more as an “impressions” tasting - how much did I enjoy the qualities I experienced, what I liked or stood out, and where does it rank compared to other things I’ve tasted, etc. 

Everything I’ve read recently about this rye is true - different, delicious, rich, flavorful, balanced, and pleasant. It got better as I went along - layers of flavors uncovering themselves on subsequent tastes. It doesn’t drink like 110 proof either.  I would definitely pick up a bottle of this later to do a proper tasting and enjoy at home for much better VFM. 

This ranks right along with the other drams I’ve rated 4 stars. It may even deserve higher. I’ll update this score accordingly when I hunt down a bottle and open it up. Highly recommended, especially if you can find it for ~$40-$45 a bottle.
This is good but it is hot. A little too spicy for me to drink straight. Would be great in an old fashioned. I prefer my ryes to be a little sweeter. The finish in this is long and peppery.

Let me start this review by complimenting the appearance of this Whiskey. A beautiful retro bottle (and cork) contains a lovely mahogany colored Rye. Now on to the tasting notes...
NOSE: Big and Bold. Dry and Dusty. Fall/Mulling Spices including Cinnamon, Clove and Orange Peel. Hay and Old Oak. The Orange Oil becomes dominant after time in the glass. A Floral Note also makes an appearance, but it flits around the edges, coming and going. There is some heat from the 110 proof. 
NEAT: Oily, Dense and Heavy. Spicy, but it enters a little sweeter than the nose would suggest with light Vanilla. Orange, Rye and Oak dominate the mid-palate. On my first pour I noted some astringency, but I get none from the second pour a couple months later. However, the Orange Oil note is much more prominent on my second tasting. Goes down with a nice warming sensation leaving a lasting coating tingly finish of White Pepper and Dry Dusty/Musty Oak. Damn this finish lasts forever, layering flavor on top of flavor with each sip. That's the hallmark of a great whiskey for me. 
SPLASH: A few drops of water makes the Orange Peel even more prominent and brings some added Brown Sugar Sweetness as well. A few more drops and the sweetness hints at Gooey Caramel. 
VERDICT: I'm glad I finally tried this one. It may be my favorite rye now that the High West Double Rye extra-aged stocks are gone. I picked this one up on sale for around $40, but it is usually closer to $50. It may not be a frequent buy for me as it is almost twice the price of Rittenhouse, but it has definitely earned a spot on my top shelf.

Neat, neck pour.  I like this a lot on the nose.  Mild rye, sweet corn, light caramel, apple.  Light oak.  So inviting for a rye.

Viscous and syrupy in texture.  Very sweet and light on the tongue.  On the taste, rye quickly gives way to a vanilla angel food cake.  Oak and caramel come back on the legs.

I know this is a barely legal rye which explains the delicious qualities and lack of spice compared to other ryes.  This is one of my favorite ryes at this price point for sure.

N(4.5). Ooooh. Rye in the face. Nose was too deep. Methanol. Peppermint. Floral of all type of flowers. Butterscotch.  Fat thick butter. Complex and amazing. 
P(4.5). Berry vanilla spice burst. Butter scotch cream frosting. Rye
F(4). Rye then vanilla cream hanging on for awhile. Got a nice bear hug.
Very nice and smooth. Would buy again!
Peppery and full bodied. Recommended by Isaiah.
One of my favorite Rye’s. Can be a little pricey, but a great sipper. Nice heat and nose.

Nice, oaky smell. The taste is oaky, rich and spicy with a hint of sweetness. 2nd place (out of 5) in a blind taste test behind Sagamore Double Oaked Rye. Very similar taste with a little less sweetness.
Strong medicine here - Pikesville makes you earn it and it's worth the effort (provided you like a young rye).
Such a fine, all purpose Rye for neat, ice or cocktails with a rather hefty proof & fair price point.
Complexe, on sent pas trop l’alcool, belle longueur. J’aime ça!
Spicy. It’s good but not great.
Smooth and strong with an excellent rye finish.  Great bourbon for a reasonable price point.  I dropped a couple cubes in to mellow it out.
Spicy and warm. I thought a minor bit woodsy. Short finish for 110 proof. Glad I bought it, but there’s other bottles I prefer when it comes to restocking.
Great rye for bourbon lovers. Gentle spice on the finish that balances perfectly with the traditional bourbon overtones.

Nose - very similar to a normal bourbon nose, lots of cherry, grape, light vanilla, caramel, woody, mild vanilla, moderate alcohol burn. 

Taste - cherry, vanilla, pepper, dry spices, fairly hot with medium oak, very subtle chocolate notes.

Helps to add a few drops of water, finishing surprisingly smooth for a high proof rye.
Dry spice bomb with some sweet vanilla and clove

This highlights rye over sweetness. The nose is eucalyptus mint and some toasted cinnamon and caramel. The pallet is sweet up front then spicy going down. Cherry and oak are added however the cherry gets dominated by the oak at the end of the bottle. A great bottle at a great price however I don’t know when I will get it again.

Nose is vanilla, grass, and spice.

Taste is fresh cereals, leather, rye spice, and a light sweetness.

Finish is long from the high proof.
Spice forward high proof, smooth finish. Great rye
My go-to rye. Right amount of heat and spice. I drink it neat, on the rocks, or mixed in a cocktail.

Spicy rye, eucalyptus, sweet sasperella. 

I've moved away from bourbon and rye drinking (or at least enjoyment of a lot of the entry to mid range stuff) in the last year or so but now and then you get flashes of perhaps not brilliance but a good combination of flavours, balance and quality at a decent price.

This is one of those drams for me that still keeps me dipping my toes and taste buds into the bourbon and rye whiskey world despite me falling out of love with the general flavour profile.

Rye spice on the nose, but also some hefty sweetness. Grain smell comes through. Rich, hefty body, medium spice, almost bourbon like sweetness. Of course a kick, but it pairs really well with the spice. Wouldn't have guessed it's as high as 110. Love this.
Strong flavor. Better palate than finish

Sweet cherry on the nose with vanilla  a hint of chocolate.

That gives a nice KY hug! 

Sweet in the palate with just a touch of spice. Not too much and very balanced.

Nose- spice - flowers - 
P- Carmel - wood - oak - leather 
Finish - hot and warm chocolate- nice burn 
Excellent rye- maybe my favorite - I picked it #1 in blind vs HM10- KC 9 yr - was very close to HM10 - but it’s finish that night was better

Blind tasting 5/3/20
(Rare Breed, Pikesville & Rowan’s Creek) 

Nose: sweet vanilla and baking spice

Palate: balanced with baking spice, tobacco with rich full flavor that coats our entire mouth

Finish: rich medium

My first attempt at a blind tasting, first bottle of rye purchased and it won the tasting.

I'm not a rye guy, but my brother is. So during Christmas we bought Old Forester 1920 and this to split. My main experiences with rye were: 1) superior ingredient to bourbon in cocktails, 2) sneaky good and cheap on the rocks options at bars like Jim Beam Rye, and 3) gross-tasting Bulleit Rye. Pikesville Rye has made me rethink the category.

The nose is so similar to high rye bourbons such as Four Roses, with just a little more cherry and rye kick. Strong aroma of orange/citrus, grass/corn dust, burnt caramel, cherries, and oak. I don't detect any licorice or eucalyptus that I've gotten in 95% rye mashbills. I really hate licorice so this was a welcome reprieve.

The high rye spice and oak continue on the palate, it definitely shows its age and proof after a few seconds. The cherry flavor really stands out on the tongue. I can see why people think cherry cola when tasting this, but honestly a sugary soda of any kind tastes nothing like whiskey. The spice really comes out in the finish, with strong peppery notes. It begins to have a cherry medicinal quality towards the end, and this is really the only thing that is holding me back from giving it a 4.5. I wish that flavored cough syrup note didn't appear.

If you're a bourbon drinker and have been turned off by high rye whiskeys, definitely try this or start cheaper with Rittenhouse. I've had a few nice ryes since purchasing Pikesville, but none have been as good.
Aroma - Peppercorn and clove. / Taste - instant rye heat that blends into leather and smoke. / finish- smooth short. Cools off really quickly.

Spicy yet sweet. 
Tobacco is present at the end with pepper
Great value. Interesting, complex and magical finish. Impress snobs with this!!

Cousin to Rittenhouse BiB rye, both Heaven Hill products (along with Larceny)(among others) great rye, creamy, just the right amount of spice.  Maryland style rye.  Great straight.  $47.00 with taxes northern Virginia.  Rittenhouse is half the price and just as good to me.
Solid favorite rye after multiple tastings

This one is surprisingly a long time coming. I'm fairly sure (although not certain) that I sampled this while at the distillery, side by side with Rittenhouse. Of course, with Rittenhouse being a superior rye, it was even more surprising to find that I fell for this one (or so I remember). So, I finally picked up a bottle of "top shelf Rittenhouse."

The nose invites fresh rye, but also a much deeper blend of spice, likely from the longer aging. It seems like a simple scent of cinnamon mellowed out with oak and caramel, but of course, the best things usually are simple.

The initial taste is almost that of a high-rye bourbon, which is to say oily, obviously full of rye spice, but letting the oak and vanilla take point. Then, like one of the best magic tricks I've seen in a while, the cinnamon (mellowed much more with age than one would taste from Rittenhouse, however) explodes forth when given air. It doesn't stop there, though; as more air is introduced, slight hints of freshly cut grass, more oak, and more of the oily body come into play, like Pikesville shouted invites from the rooftops to this party that they're having.

The finish, as a good rye whiskey should be, burns the mouth, but not from alcohol, oh no, but with the cinnamon spice of a challenging spice candy. It's a much longer finish than that of Rittenhouse, which really defines who the big brother is here. If my distillery adventure truly wasn't a fever dream, then me saying out loud during tasting, "I remember why I love this whiskey so much" makes sense. Thank your god that the Heaven Hill bandwagon finally broke down. I like their products as much as any other normal collector, but now that the media train is on Buffalo Trace (for reasons unknown to the universe), I can seemingly enjoy their products, including this one, much more now that I can find it without going on side quests.
Drinks cooler than proof would hint at. And has a delicious baking spice flavors.

Creamy with a bite in the back of the throat
Unfolds on your palette like a blossoming Peacock 

Makes an exceptional Manhattan with black walnut bitter and excellent vermouth

This definitely highlights the rye over sweetness factor. For a rye, it’s rare for me to get one where the flavors even out in smokiness and sweetness, though. This is a rye I like to use to make for a little twist on an old fashion. And I just keep coming back to it.
Recommended based on a great price. Very good, strong rye, but still not my favorite. Worth a buy if you're a rye fan.

Aroma: Green Apple and Cinnamon/Sugar Toast with hints of Floral
Texture: Silky Velvet
Flavor: Buttery Caramel Biscuit
Finish: Cinnamon, Leather, Caramel Char and subtle Mint

Very nutty like heavy roasted peanuts and vanilla nose with a hint of ethanol.  Carmel first thing then strong ethanol on the tongue with lots barrel char and tons of spice on the mid. Finishes with more ethanol. Lots of rye spices. Little water helps level it but still to much spice for me.
